The foundations of quantum mechanics are a major open problem in the history of science. The Copenhagen interpretation, which has been widely accepted, is based on a set of axioms that are not fully satisfactory. In this paper, we provide a set of axioms for quantum mechanics that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum mechanics raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. Our axioms are based on the notion of a category of observables, which is a purely categorical generalization of the notion of a vector space. Our results provide a categorical foundation for quantum mechanics that is independent of any analytical structure. They also provide a categorical framework for the study of quantum information theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two distantly related species of myxozoans, which show that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. Our results provide insights into the molecular basis for the evolution of the Myxozoa. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used to ensure their replication and propagation. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) and thereby impair the induction of antiviral genes. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of the karyopherin/importin complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to antagonize the action of IFN. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune system and suggests potential therapeutic targets to combat the ongoing pandemic. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This instability in global grain trade and international grain prices will affect especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero for the top four maize-exporting countries, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species differ in their diets is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa from plant material. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between species, even when they were matched in body size and digestive physiology. Moreover, species that were similar in diet composition were often dissimilar in their proportional grass consumption, indicating that diet composition is a more important determinant of coexistence than proportional grass consumption. These findings suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages. Our results also highlight the importance of plant diversity in structuring LMH assemblages. This is an important step toward understanding the role of LMH in the conservation of African savanna biodiversity.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and many plan to apply for government loans. However, many anticipate problems accessing the loans, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris load in the open ocean is far less than expected, mostly because of size-selective sinks. These sinks are likely to be related to the rapid fragmentation of plastic debris into smaller and smaller pieces, which are then transported to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes. This study is of fundamental importance to understand the fate of the missing plastic debris in the ocean. It also provides a new perspective on the role of size-selective sinks in the fate of particles in the environment. This study may also help to improve the design of future experiments and models.

The origin of the elements is one of the most important questions in astrophysics. The interstellar medium is the site of nucleosynthesis of the elements heavier than hydrogen and helium. The cosmic ray exposure ages of presolar grains, which are the first solids formed in stars, provide information about the age of the interstellar medium. We determined ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is consistent with the age of the Solar System. However, a minority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is much older than the Solar System. We estimate that the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This result is important for the understanding of the origin of the elements. It also provides information about the age of the first stars and the epoch of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, with the motorized fleet expanding rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could increase by 1 million more motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of life. In placental mammals, the mother’s ability to reproduce is limited by her own metabolic power. This is because the energy required to produce offspring is equal to the energy produced by the offspring. We show that the ability to provide energy to the mother, either through domestication or allonursing, can increase reproductive output. This increase is not due to an increase in resource availability, but rather an increase in metabolic power. This suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals is metabolic power rather than resource availability.

Alpha-synuclein (α-syn) is a protein that is implicated in the pathogenesis of several neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple system atrophy (MSA). MSA is a sporadic disorder with a poor prognosis, and no treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form that is known to be neurotoxic. In addition, VX-765 was able to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of the mouse model. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to specific stimuli. The endothelium is a highly interconnected network of cells that must be able to rapidly and efficiently communicate with each other to control vascular function. Here, we show that the endothelium is a small-world network, which is a property of networks in which the number of connections between cells is short between local clusters of cells and long between distant cells. This property allows for rapid and efficient communication between cells. The small-world network design of the endothelium is effective for controlling vascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health authorities and epidemiologists. We present a data-sharing API that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These include signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data and software are available for free download and use. We believe that this data sharing will help to empower researchers and decision makers in their efforts to understand and respond to the pandemic.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. The activation gate closes when the selectivity filter is open, and vice versa. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that a Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position leads to the loss of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of the allosteric coupling. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. Our findings provide a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. They also provide a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation in the absence of the TTVGYGD signature sequence. This knowledge may be useful for the development of potassium channel modulators.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem of bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms that are essential for the health of the animal. The gut microbiome of herbivores is also highly dynamic, with the composition of the microbiome changing over time and in response to environmental and dietary factors. The gut microbiome of herbivores is poorly understood, and the role of the microbiome in the health of the animal is not fully appreciated. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased reactive oxygen species production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired behaviors is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and the design of a specific structure are often limited to the realization of a limited range of behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis and fabrication strategy to design and manufacture multifunctional mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme responses. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The digitally synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design multifunctional mechanical devices with specific target behaviors for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design and manufacture multifunctional mechanical devices with desired behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans and other vertebrates. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of aging. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in humans. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is silenced in the adult bone marrow. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This reversal is mediated by reduced expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of anemia in aging and other diseases. They also suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a useful biomarker for the differentiation of fetal from adult hematopoietic cells. Finally, they suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a useful therapeutic target for the treatment of anemia in aging and other diseases.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway are resistant to ferroptosis, and that this resistance is mediated by activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for cancer cells to survive ferroptosis. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. This strategy could be applied to a wide range of cancers, including those with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway, such as breast and prostate cancer. These findings also suggest that ferroptosis may be a useful therapeutic target in cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers (LCCBs). These drugs are effective in lowering blood pressure, but their long-term use is associated with adverse effects. Here, we show that LCCBs activate the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) Ca2+ sensor STIM1 and the plasma membrane ORAI1 channels, which promote vascular remodeling. Our data indicate that LCCBs are more associated with heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs in patients. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. These findings may help to improve the safety of LCCBs in patients. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but that the policy has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older forests. The NWFP has not been effective in halting the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations, and the creation of early-seral ecosystems may impede the development of older-forest structure. These findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a long and expensive process, which is why it is necessary to identify promising candidates as early as possible. In this study, we present a computational approach to identify promising acylide antibiotics that can be used to combat antibiotic resistance. We show that our approach is successful in identifying promising candidates that are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The best candidate identified by us is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our study provides a proof of concept for the use of computational approaches in the early identification of promising antibiotics. This approach can be used to identify promising candidates for the treatment of other diseases in the future.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The shift in hydroclimate is consistent with a change in climate forcing, consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The record provides insights into the influence of orbital forcing on the evolution of the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock. The extreme hydroclimate variability exerted a profound influence on the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock; the geographically extensive habitat reconfiguration provided novel ecological opportunities, enabling new populations to differentiate rapidly to distinct species.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the biological effects of this exposure on sleep are unknown. Here we compare the effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) with reading a printed book in the hours before bedtime. We found that reading an LE-eBook phase-decelerates the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is a 100-y-long period of abrupt climate change that occurred 11,600 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites is consistent with terrestrial Os in bulk samples from these sites. In contrast, the Os isotopic composition of bulk samples from the YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania is inconsistent with Os in bulk samples from these sites. The Os isotopic composition of spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania is consistent with Os in the spherules. The Os isotopic composition of the spherules and their leachates is likely terrestrial. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the YDB cooling. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. Moreover, we show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity induced by adoptive transfer of T cells, but not by the development of autoimmunity induced by immunization. These findings indicate that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the thymus and periphery. Thus, CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the thymus and periphery. (Show more)

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this insect order remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to show that beetles diversified during the Carboniferous, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. These novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that beetle diversity resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. This study provides insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that, contrary to popular belief, population size does not enhance CCE. Instead, it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology in general and for the design of cultural evolution experiments in particular.

The apoE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk. However, the mechanisms by which APOE influences AD risk are not known. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles influence the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide insights into the mechanisms by which APOE influences AD risk. They also suggest that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which may be a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,200 km in diameter and 1,200 km in height. It is the densest material in the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.6 g/cm3, which is 10 times that of water. The inner core is a mystery because it is not known how it formed. The most popular theory is that it formed by direct nucleation of the stable, hexagonal close-packed phase of iron. However, this theory is not supported by the available data. We show that the nucleation of the stable phase is not the first step of the inner core formation. Instead, the nucleation of the metastable, body-centered cubic phase of iron is the first step, which is supported by our experiments and simulations. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. The effects of marijuana on the brain are not well understood, and the consequences of chronic marijuana use are unknown. We found that marijuana abusers show reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]), including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and in the brain’s reward system. These findings suggest that marijuana abusers have decreased brain reactivity to DA stimulation, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is the defining cognitive skill of the human brain. Yet, despite its importance, our understanding of how the human brain processes language is limited. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural network language models can predict brain responses to spoken sentences in humans and predict how well participants will perform on a next-word prediction task. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the brain’s language machinery is more similar to a modern artificial neural network than was previously thought. Together, these results have implications for our understanding of the human brain and language. They also have the potential to inform the design of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in computer science, but it has not been used in scientific computing because of its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that DL methods are not well-conditioned problems. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a fundamental result that will guide the development of scientific computing with deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past epidemics. One of the most frequently cited studies in this context is a classic experiment published in 1972, which purported to show that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This study has been widely misrepresented as evidence for this claim, and its flaws have been overlooked. Here, we discuss the study’s methodology in detail, show that it is fundamentally flawed, and argue that this is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. The genome sequence of a new species, M. lepromatosis, provides insights into the evolutionary history of leprosy. The two leprosy species are remarkably conserved, and the genome sequence suggests that they are still capable of causing disease. The findings also suggest that the two species have been able to maintain their pathogenicity despite a long period of separation. This may be due to the fact that the two species have retained the ability to infect the nervous system, which is the primary site of disease in leprosy. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two pillars of quantum information science, which is the scientific field that studies quantum computers. The entanglement dynamics is a key ingredient in the study of quantum quenches, which are a paradigmatic example of a quantum dynamical process. However, the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit is a very hard problem, which has been studied so far only for noninteracting systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the interacting system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is a major step forward in our understanding of the entanglement dynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide and has severely affected the global economy. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, which may be difficult to achieve in low-income countries. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is highly attenuated, and the viral load in the lungs is lower in hamsters vaccinated with the vaccine compared to those vaccinated with the wild-type virus. The vaccine is also protective in hamsters challenged with the wild-type virus. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to control the pandemic. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were responsible for the spread of the disease. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which is supported by the historical mortality curves of nine outbreaks in Europe. Our results suggest that human ectoparasites were the primary vectors of plague during the Second Pandemic, challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides insights into the history of plague and the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of this disease. It also provides a framework for understanding the role of ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience for more than a century. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity, which is the ultimate goal of evolution, has been largely ignored. This study shows that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also has a complex pattern. The evolution of brain information-processing capacity is characterized by four major shifts in the number of neurons, which are associated with the evolution of birds and primates. These results have important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. Some studies have shown that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others have shown that it is an oncogene. Here we show that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator that promotes a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data provide a mechanistic basis for the observed correlation between TRAP1 expression and tumor grade in several cancers. The TRAP1-Src interaction provides a potential therapeutic target for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. Severing is a key step in many cellular processes, including cell motility and cytokinesis. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin severes actin filaments is unknown. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin binds to and severes actin filaments more efficiently when the filaments are under mechanical stress. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history and culture. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a recent settlement of Madagascar, with a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous admixture. These results suggest that Madagascar was settled by multiple independent waves of people, rather than by an already admixed population. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it can be used to understand the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. It also provides a framework to study the history of other populations with a similar grid-based approach.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This is a surprising result, because it suggests that people can be influenced by the emotions of others without having direct contact with them. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others, even when the content of the posts is reduced to only factual information. This work has implications for understanding the spread of emotions in social networks, and for the design of social media platforms.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is translated into proteins, and the sequence of nucleotides in the mRNA is critical for this process. One of the most common modifications in mRNA is pseudouridine (Ψ), which is present in 10–20% of the nucleotides in coding regions. We show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter translation speed and the ability of the ribosome to decode mRNA codons. These findings suggest that mRNA sequences containing Ψ can have subtle effects on protein synthesis, which may have important implications for gene expression regulation. Our work also provides insights into how the ribosome encounters Ψ in mRNA. These findings highlight the complexity of mRNA sequences and the many ways in which they can influence protein synthesis. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and greater use of time. These findings have implications for public health and for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of aquatic lifestyles has been a major driver of evolutionary change in mammals, but the extent to which aquatic lifestyles have driven the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals remains unclear. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and the fossil record to show that aquatic mammals have evolved toward a common size attractor, which is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment. These results provide a mechanistic explanation for the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals and suggest that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles may have been a major driver of evolutionary change in mammals.

The common cold is the most common viral infection worldwide, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the cause of 50% of all colds. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a more efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here we show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a more efficient antiviral defense response at core body temperature, which correlates with higher levels of type I and type III IFNs and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings suggest that the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is, at least in part, a consequence of the host antiviral response. Our results also suggest that the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication may be a target for antiviral therapy. (Show more)

Bacteria use a variety of sensory systems to sense their environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanosensory system is required for attachment to surfaces, which in turn promotes the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. Our results demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This finding provides insights into the evolution of bacterial mechanosensory systems and the mechanisms by which bacteria sense and respond to their environment. It also suggests that type IV pili may be a promising target for the development of new antibiotics. This work also provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria sense surfaces and may be used to develop new strategies to control bacterial infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades, and the number of pesticides available to farmers is constantly growing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, showing that the use of pesticides in agriculture is associated with a substantial risk to the quality of surface water. The results of this study are alarming, as the quality of surface water is essential for the survival of aquatic organisms and for the provision of ecosystem services such as drinking water production. The results of this study suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture should be reduced, and that the existing regulations should be enforced more strictly.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of emerging viruses and the role of animals in their spread. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease and can act as a reservoir for the virus. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer, and that the virus has likely spread between humans and deer through multiple human-to-deer transmission events. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic and highlight the need for a more proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. This paper examines the problems associated with the construction of large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to Aβ deposits and cell death. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of mounting an inflammatory response to Aβ, even in the absence of cell death or extracellular plaques. We identify a unique neuron-specific inflammatory profile, which may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis. Our findings suggest that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis, and may represent a therapeutic target for the treatment of the disease.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is known from the Hellenistic period in the Southern Levant. We show that the frequency of chicken bones in the Southern Levant is much higher than in any other region in the ancient Near East and is comparable to that in Europe. This suggests that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on nascent RNA molecules. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study reveals a mechanism for how a bacterial enzyme can recognize and deprotect capped RNA termini in a manner distinct from the one it uses to deprotect other 5′ termini. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the pathogenesis of the disease. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also show that arginine supplementation is more efficient than citrulline supplementation in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results suggest that arginine supplementation could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the biomass of humans and other taxa for the functioning of the ecosystem. This work provides a quantitative view of the biomass of the biosphere that can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. It also provides a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the biomass of the biosphere. This work is a step toward a better understanding of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and physics, in which a system can self-adjust its dynamics to maintain a critical state. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, a self-organized criticality (SOC) mechanism, and a nontrivial scaling limit. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with a power-law distribution of activity and a nontrivial scaling limit. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of intersexual communication, and the molecular nature of this communication is largely unknown. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. The database is publicly available and can be used to study the human virome in the context of human disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability to simultaneously measure the diurnal aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties. Here, we introduce a dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) to overcome this conundrum. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to contribute to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This work will help to improve the representation of ACI in climate models. This will help to improve the prediction of climate change. This will also help to improve the prediction of weather and climate.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for reconstructing ancient surface temperatures based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow across the plasma membrane. They are also the main targets of drugs and toxins. Ion channels are classified into three types based on their pore structures. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a type-3 channel that lacks a classic activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels have a unique slow C-type inactivation that is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. It also provides a new target for the development of drugs and toxins that selectively target the BK channel. (Show more)

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite exploits the physical properties of the RBC to facilitate invasion. We show that the parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen, EBA175, alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a mechanistic explanation for the role of EBA175 in malaria parasite invasion and opens up the possibility of targeting this interaction as a potential therapeutic strategy. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. Our study may also have implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral therapeutics. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this structure is indirect and based on the assumption that the brain’s activity increases monotonically with the complexity of the linguistic object under consideration. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases monotonically with the complexity of the linguistic object, but only when the object is a phrase. Our results provide direct evidence for the existence of a merge operation in the brain, which applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. The merge operation is consistent with a neural implementation of a left-corner parser, which is necessary for the correct interpretation of complex sentences. Our findings have important implications for the design of artificial intelligence systems.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates cell fate decisions and tissue patterning. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, and that this differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to Wnt signals.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region for the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the midbrain. This circuit is not involved in the control of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a global concern. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, early deforestation alerts rarely reach the most directly affected populations in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. The estimated effects were largest in communities facing the largest threats. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sound sources in their environment. The hearing organs of animals are diverse in anatomy and are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is made of protein and is self-manufactured, so it is not constrained by the body size of the spider. The spider can therefore hear over a wide range of distances and angles, and it can also hear through obstacles. The spider’s web is a unique acoustic sensor that is supersized and can be regenerated. This provides insights into the evolution of hearing in animals and the design of acoustic sensors. It also provides a model system for studying the sensing of fluid flow.

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric cancer of neural crest-derived tissues. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALs activate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro and in vivo. We further show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Finally, we show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for zebrafish development and that loss of ALKALs causes a lethal phenotype. The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex and poorly understood process. We present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. Our results show that the earliest Y. pestis lineages were nonflea-adapted and likely extinct, and that the flea-adapted form of the pathogen emerged in the Bronze Age in Iberia, a region previously thought to be a secondary source of plague. Our data also reveal a stepwise pattern of gene loss in the earliest lineages, which may have been a key step in the pathogen’s evolution. These findings provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its relationship to its vector, the flea, and may help to inform future efforts to control and eradicate this devastating disease. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a key question in climate change mitigation and adaptation. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has released massive amounts of SOC to the atmosphere, but the efficacy of different soil health management practices in sequestering SOC in agricultural systems remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that incorporate perennial pastures and livestock can sequester SOC and increase the use of soil organic matter by soil microbes. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to mitigate climate change and support food security.

We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators is nectar, which is produced by specialized glands in the flower. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinators to find the plant, but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid called nesocodin. We also identify a convergent evolution of red nectar in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of a visually important trait in plants and the mechanisms that underlie the production of nectar. This work also highlights the importance of alkaloid chemistry in the evolution of floral rewards.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood, as there are no population-level genome data from this time period. Here we present genome data from 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. We find that the men in our sample have ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while the women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. This study also highlights the importance of functional variants in understanding the history of European populations. (Show more)

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, were investigated. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human cell entry, contributing to the enhanced pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. These results suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings also provide insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the evolution of bat coronaviruses. They are expected to contribute to the development of strategies for the prevention and control of future bat coronavirus-related threats to human health. (Show more)

The ability to rapidly identify the pathogen responsible for an undifferentiated febrile illness is critical for the early deployment of public health response. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of RNA extracted from serum samples of febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. Our findings highlight the importance of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to rapidly identify the pathogen responsible for an undifferentiated febrile illness and inform the deployment of public health response. This study also demonstrates the feasibility of using a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of RNA extracted from serum samples of febrile patients in resource-scarce settings. The lagging strand of the genome is replicated by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in a processive, sliding clamp-dependent manner. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of PCNA in DNA replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is a central question in biology. One hypothesis is that life began with the evolution of RNA, which served as the first genetic material. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. The polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate RNA, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the polymerase ribozyme can serve as the basis for the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies, but it is difficult to observe and measure. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements, and neighborhoods that are physically attractive to others experience, on average, larger positive improvements. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that urban change is not a uniform process but rather is shaped by the physical characteristics of neighborhoods. The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is a promising treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but excess copper is toxic to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is unknown. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. These copper-dependent antifungal properties of xan BGC metabolites are demonstrated in vitro and in vivo. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings provide insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the impact of copper on fungal physiology. This knowledge may be useful in the development of antifungal agents. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is consistent with high-temperature, low-pressure conditions of formation. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and the amorphous silica, and is possibly derived from silicic volcanism in the crater wall/rim/central peak region. The amorphous silica is cogenetic with the mixed-cation salts and oxides and possibly the crystalline magnetite, and is possibly derived from multiple aqueous solutions with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The mixed-cation salts and oxides are possibly derived from the same aqueous solutions as the amorphous silica. The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a new and unexpected discovery.

Frost is a major environmental stressor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not well adapted to the new frost regimes. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. They also provide a framework for understanding the impact of other environmental stressors, such as drought, on the performance of plants and animals.

Th17 cells are a recently identified subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear whether Th17 cells are required for the development of disease or whether they are simply mediators of the inflammatory response. Here we show that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis and that they can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease pathogenesis may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by motor neuron toxicity. However, the mechanisms of motor neuron toxicity are not fully understood. Here we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and develop therapeutics. This method will also enable high-throughput screening of drugs to identify those that alleviate motor neuron toxicity. This will greatly advance ALS disease modeling and drug discovery. This work also provides a platform for studying other neurodegenerative diseases. This work will also enable high-throughput screening of drugs to identify those that alleviate motor neuron toxicity. The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization and development. However, the ways in which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors to enhance colonization are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that alters the gut microbiota of the vector, I. scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. IAFGP alters the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier, two critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. Mechanistically, IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors to enhance colonization. This knowledge may be useful for the development of vector control strategies. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. The short-tailed bird group Pygostylia is a major evolutionary lineage that has been hypothesized to have contributed to the evolution of the modern avian body plan. However, the currently limited known diversity of early branching members of Pygostylia obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the evolution of the avian body plan. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have evolved a variety of mechanisms to avoid detection by predators, including color patterns that blend with the background. These color patterns are often associated with the presence of unusual pigments, such as biliverdin, which is a precursor of the green pigment chlorophyll. Here, we show that the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is linked to the presence of a specific class of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins, are most similar to human antiproteases, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. The ability of cancer cells to maintain their stemness properties is critical for tumor growth and metastasis. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of the pluripotency factor NANOG. We also show that ALKBH5 expression is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cell properties in response to hypoxia. These findings suggest that ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. Our study also provides insight into the role of m6A modification in the regulation of cancer stem cells. (Show more)

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world, and the first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these Bibles has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did find evidence for the use of more than one species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The method could be used to identify the source of other materials, such as animal skins, that are used in the production of books. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, with some researchers attributing it to a single trigger, others to a combination of triggers, and still others to a combination of causes and processes. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding the extinction and its causes. The age model presented here is based on the precise dating of volcanic ash beds that mark the Permian-Triassic boundary. The age model is consistent with the hypothesis that the extinction was caused by a combination of triggers and processes. The age model also provides a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model is also consistent with the hypothesis that the recovery from the extinction was slow and incomplete. The age model is also consistent with the hypothesis that the recovery was slower in the terrestrial realm than in the marine realm.
