Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive activation of the immune system. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and involves multiple factors, including genetic factors, environmental factors, and the immune system. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of IBD and suggest that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of IBD. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, and the human ACE2 protease cleavage site. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation that may facilitate binding to the receptor. This finding may help to explain why the D614G mutation is so prevalent in the current circulating virus. The structure of the spike may also provide a target for the development of new antiviral drugs. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our projections imply that the Black−White life expectancy gap would increase by nearly 40% and that Latinos would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings underscore the need for public health interventions to reduce the racial and ethnic disparities in COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. Our projections also highlight the importance of addressing the social determinants of health, such as poverty, food insecurity, and housing instability, which have been shown to increase risk of exposure to and mortality from COVID-19. Our projections underscore the need for public health interventions to reduce the racial and ethnic disparities in COVID-19 morbidity and mortality.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the starting point for understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we show that pressure can change the chemical properties of atoms, and that these changes can be predicted by a simple model. This work can be seen as a first step toward understanding the chemistry of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, but the impact of this on the global carbon cycle is uncertain. We show that changes in human demography, such as population growth and migration, can reduce the frequency of wildfires, which in turn can reduce warming. This effect is most pronounced under lower emissions scenarios, and it is important to consider the role of human demography in future fire regimes. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to understand the feedbacks between climate, fire, and the carbon cycle.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which host-derived nutrients are delivered to the symbiotic epithelium are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, through a circadian rhythm. This glycan is required for the maturation of the symbiotic organ, which is used for bioluminescence. Our results suggest that the provision of nutrients to the epithelium-associated microbiota may be a more general mechanism for regulating the stability of animal–microbe associations. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that other hosts may also regulate the activities of their symbiotic microbes through the strategic provision of specific nutrients. Such a strategy could be particularly important for animals that live in complex environments, where the provision of nutrients may be the only way to maintain a stable symbiosis. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as sequences of latent patterns. We first identify a set of latent patterns that provide a sparse representation of an embedding space. We then infer the latent patterns that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. This approach can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos.

The Black Death, which killed an estimated 30–50% of Europe’s population, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. The disease originated in Asia and spread to Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate in the Asian source region of the disease was favorable for the survival of the bacterium, while the climate in Europe was not. This suggests that the bacterium was repeatedly introduced into European harbors, which were the main entry points for the disease into Europe. Our results provide evidence for a climate-driven reintroduction of the bacterium into European harbors, which is consistent with the hypothesis that the disease was maintained in Europe for centuries by repeated introductions of the pathogen. This study provides evidence for the importance of climate in the spread of the Black Death. It also provides a new approach to study the spread of infectious diseases in the past, which can be applied to other diseases. (Show more)

Asteroids are a common species of the Northeast Pacific Ocean, and their populations have recently experienced an extensive outbreak of a disease that has led to rapid degradation of the animals. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by starfish. The virus is likely to have been present in the region for at least 72 y, and it is therefore the most promising candidate disease agent responsible for asteroid mass mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML patients is poor. The identification of targets for therapeutic intervention is therefore of great importance. Here we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML. The findings are relevant for the development of new treatment strategies for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history and culture. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a recent settlement of Madagascar, with a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous admixture. These results suggest that Madagascar was colonized by different groups from Africa and Asia, rather than a single population, and that the recent settlement of Madagascar happened in a few centuries. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean region. They also provide a new approach to study the history of human populations. This approach can be used to study other islands and regions with a limited population size. This approach can also be used to study the history of other regions of the world.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases dehydrogenase activity and represses genes involved in glycerol metabolism. The protein interacts with the enzyme glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and the RNA represses genes involved in glycerol metabolism by competing with the protein for translation. This demonstrates that the translation and base-pairing functions of sRNAs compete. This finding has implications for the evolution of sRNAs and the regulation of metabolism. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are often not used in agricultural decision-making. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition survey of the US Department of Agriculture can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited for quantitative analysis. We also show that the Crop Condition Index based on this data can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of using crop expert assessments to improve agricultural decision-making and highlight the importance of harnessing the power of “people as sensors” in the digital age.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. We show that these changes can be used to store information on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great scientific interest and societal importance. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is marked by a gradual change in the selective pressure on the genome. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis itself. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. The evolutionary rates of plastid genes are linked to the extent of functional reduction, which in turn is linked to the establishment of the parasitic lifestyle. These findings may have implications for the evolution of other organelles and for the evolution of life itself. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also show that the drought risk in SSA will increase with global warming, even under a low-emission scenario. This underscores the need for urgent mitigation efforts. Our results also show that the drought risk in SSA will increase with global warming, even under a low-emission scenario. This underscores the need for urgent mitigation efforts.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was a major scientific event. The discovery of quasicrystals in the red trinitite, the only material from the test that survived, is a major scientific event of a different kind. The trinitite quasicrystal is the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, and its discovery provides a unique link between the discovery of quasicrystals and the history of the atomic bomb.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase” reaction, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the catalytic component of which is a diiron protein. Here we show that the diiron enzyme is required for oxygenic photosynthesis, and that the diiron enzyme is required for oxygenic photosynthesis, and that the diiron enzyme is required for oxygenic photosynthesis, and that the diiron enzyme is required for the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring. These data delineate three classes of the enzyme in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria. The evolution of these enzymes is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS), and is also known to be associated with other neurological disorders. Neuroinflammation is a complex process involving multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, critically low reservoir storage, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in recent decades, and that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased. We also find that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. Thus, anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the 2012–2014 drought in California. This finding has important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate adaptation planning in California and elsewhere. It also suggests that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of drought in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the prevalence of negativity biases in news content across a large, representative sample of the world’s population. Results show that, on average, news content is overwhelmingly negative, and that this negativity is associated with increased heart rate, skin conductance, and blood pressure. These results are consistent across 17 countries, 6 continents, and a wide range of sociopolitical contexts. They also highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content, suggesting that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, but its physiological role has been difficult to determine because of the lack of a functional genetic tool to study its function. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 that result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, leading to hematological abnormalities and myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, demonstrating that they are not cleared by the normal clearance pathways. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on endocytosis in the spreading neurons, and that this can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These studies provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for studying the mechanisms of spreading in other neurodegenerative diseases. This work provides a proof of principle for using Drosophila as a model to study the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases.

The identification of the immunologically privileged sites in bats is of great importance for understanding the mechanisms of host–pathogen interactions and for the development of therapeutic strategies to combat emerging infectious diseases. Here, we identified and characterized a highly concentrated immunosuppressant protein (MTX) in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX selectively inhibited the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTB4 generation and the antiviral immune response of the host. MTX had no effect on the aminopeptidase function of LTA4H and therefore did not impair the antiinflammatory function of LTA4H. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The identification of MTX and its role in the immune system of bats may provide a new perspective for the development of therapeutic strategies to combat emerging infectious diseases. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus cancer cells must meet the increased demand for one-carbon units for nucleotide synthesis. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT) isoforms, and have shown that dual inhibition of SHMT1/2 blocks colon cancer tumor growth in vivo. We have also shown that formate, a one-carbon unit, is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of B-cell cancers. We have identified a glycine import defect in a subset of B-cell cancers, and thus have identified a targetable metabolic deficiency of B-cell cancers. These studies have identified a metabolic vulnerability of B-cell cancers that can be exploited therapeutically. This work has implications for the treatment of other cancers that have a similar metabolic vulnerability. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins, including the well-known superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), the transactive response DNA binding protein 43 (TDP-43), and the fused in sarcoma (FUS) protein. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the inclusion bodies are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies are populated by proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This finding provides a mechanistic explanation for the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal band structures are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for quantum simulation of many-body physics, quantum sensing, and quantum information science. The photonic crystal system is also a promising platform for quantum simulation of many-body physics, quantum sensing, and quantum information science.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The earliest flowering plants were aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The study of Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees, shows that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution. This study also shows that aquatic plants were not confined to a single ecological niche but diversified into a variety of habitats. The study of Montsechia also raises questions about the position of aquatic plants in the evolution of the Ceratophyllum clade.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that has been associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland, which show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

The rate at which the Earth is accelerating is one of the most important indicators of the state of the climate system. The acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y is estimated to be 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, which is consistent with the rate of climate-change–driven sea level rise. This result is also consistent with the rate of acceleration estimated from the rate of change of the length of the day, which is a key indicator of the climate system.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that pain has increased more for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is seen across measures of pain, including self-report, medical records, and mortality data. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is seen in the erosion of pain.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of chemical intermediates in enzyme active sites is a key goal in mechanistic enzymology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides insight into the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site, the protonation states of the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains, and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This detailed picture of the intermediate and its reactivity is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole reacts, but the isostere benzimidazole does not. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that the antiviral drug remdesivir effectively inhibited MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV) replication in vitro, and showed efficacy against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. We also show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection prevented disease, reduced virus replication, and decreased the severity of lung lesions. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great benefit to patients and the global community. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which host-derived nutrients are delivered to the symbiotic epithelium are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, through a circadian rhythm. This glycan is required for the maturation of the symbiotic organ, which is used for bioluminescence. Our results suggest that the provision of nutrients to the epithelium-associated microbiota may be a more general mechanism for regulating the stability of animal–microbe associations. This idea is supported by the observation that other animals may also regulate the activities of their symbiotic microbes through the strategic provision of specific nutrients. Such a strategy could be particularly important for animals that live in complex environments, where the availability of nutrients may vary diurnally. (Show more)

The suspension rate in US schools is 10 times higher than in the 1970s, and it is rising. Suspension is a costly and ineffective response to misbehavior, and it is associated with long-term negative consequences for students. We show that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can be sustained through a brief, online intervention.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. The transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. The requirement for sequential proteolysis in MERS-CoV infection may be a common feature of coronaviruses. This study provides insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and may have implications for the development of MERS-CoV vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Show more)

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and the global population is expected to increase by 2.5 billion by 2050. The food system also contributes to the global burden of diet-related noncommunicable diseases, which are the leading cause of death worldwide. The food system could be made more sustainable by increasing the proportion of plant-based meals offered in catering settings. This study provides robust evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in a catering setting can lead to substantial increases in sales of vegetarian meals. This is a promising finding for the food system, public health, and the environment.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space, and is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study how six of the most prominent oncogenes remodel the surfaceome in a cell autologous fashion. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, the effects of vote-by-mail have been the subject of much debate, with some scholars claiming that vote-by-mail increases turnout and decreases partisanship, while others claim that vote-by-mail decreases turnout and increases partisanship. We provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the virus and its molecular basis for disease. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2, and the presence of this interface may contribute to the immune evasion and disease severity observed with SARS-CoV-2. This work provides a molecular understanding of the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. This work also provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis for the evolution of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying hypoxia-induced cerebral edema are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia triggers cortical release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxia-induced edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this potentially fatal condition. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It addresses the question of how to properly assess the strength of associations when we have selected a subset of the data to analyze. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks in tissue regeneration and for the treatment of vascular disorders. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 induces expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders and for the regeneration of vascular networks in tissue regeneration. (Show more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the oncogenic receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research in the field of RTKs. Here, we show that augmentor ligands are essential for zebrafish iridophore patterning and that these ligands are activated by Ltk and not by Alk. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the function of RTKs in vivo and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer patients. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder characterized by insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. The role of STING in T2D remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells and peripheral tissues beneficially ameliorated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance, whereas STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. STING deficiency in β-cells decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Moreover, STING deficiency in β-cells decreased nuclear localization of Pax6, a transcription factor that is required for β-cell function. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of STING in T2D and establish the pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings also provide a rationale for the development of STING-targeted therapies for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are composed of eight genomic RNA segments, which are packaged into virions. The packaging mechanism is still unknown, and it is suspected that one copy of each RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also showed that this interaction favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the development of atherosclerotic lesions, which are composed of a core of fatty streaks and an outer layer of inflammatory cells. The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key environmental factor that promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying the disturbed flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions are largely unknown. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a molecular basis for the disturbed flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Therefore, this study provides a molecular understanding of the disturbed flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development and may lead to the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and this has increased the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the role of humans in increasing the extent of wildfire in the United States. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that this expansion has occurred over the last 30 y. We also show that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occur in areas where fuel moisture is higher, thereby helping to expand the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. These findings highlight the need for increased management of human-caused wildfires to reduce the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies, but it is difficult to observe and measure. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study urban change in other cities and in other countries. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. The study also provides a model for the evolution of insect–plant interactions. This work may also help to conserve biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the symbiotic relationship between corals and their algal partners, which is triggered by heat stress. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which in turn is a consequence of the energy limitation of the coral host. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the processes that lead to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis and may help to identify ways to mitigate the damage to coral reefs.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the host–microbe interaction. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the microbiome and that the microbiome can alter the activity of the tumor. We also show that restoring the activity of the intestinal epithelium restores homeostasis and extends lifespan. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK signaling pathway to maintain intestinal barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing strategies to control tumorigenesis. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing strategies to control tumorigenesis. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK signaling pathway to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing strategies to control tumorigenesis. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK signaling pathway

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and many patients endure multiple rounds of treatment. In some cases, chemotherapy may select for cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Furthermore, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can repress expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impair the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. Thus, the results of this study may have important implications for the treatment of breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the Antarctic ozone hole and its impact on Southern Hemisphere climate has been a matter of intense debate. Here we show that the start of the Antarctic ozone hole in 1979 coincided with the start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere. We show that the deglaciation was triggered by a volcanic eruption, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, and that these events occurred exactly at the start of accelerated deglaciation. This finding has important implications for the causes of Antarctic ozone depletion and its impact on Southern Hemisphere climate. It also provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can trigger climate change. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries sustainability and biodiversity conservation. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our results highlight the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need to protect these ecosystems from the impacts of overfishing and other threats. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the proposed material are responsible for the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. The proposed material is also promising for other aqueous energy devices.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, however, the CNS is largely incapable of regenerating after injury, and the regeneration capacity of the PNS is even more limited. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the nematode C. elegans that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway known to mediate regeneration in the CNS of other species. We also identify a form of regeneration in the mammalian CNS that is reminiscent of the C. elegans DLK-independent regeneration. These connections suggest that the C. elegans DLK-independent regeneration represents a powerful platform for gene discovery in the regeneration of the adult mammalian nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the C. elegans DLK-independent regeneration represents a powerful platform for gene discovery in the regeneration of the adult mammalian nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create genetic diversity. In sexually reproducing organisms, recombination is essential for the formation of offspring with unique combinations of genes. In the past, recombination rates were high, but over evolutionary time, they have decreased in many regions of the genome, leaving the reasons for this change unclear. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination rates in a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and show that the distribution is similar to that in yeast and in mice that lack a particular gene family of zinc finger proteins. This suggests that the patterns we describe may be ancient and conserved.

The resting brain is a dynamic, highly organized system, with a complex network topology. The present study provides a method for identifying and validating the resting state network organization in healthy and disease populations. The results show that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients. The results show that the dominant resting state network is functionally deactivating during rest, and this deactivation is reduced in advanced Parkinson’s disease. This study provides a method for assessing the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of mRNA is known to regulate translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in yeast, which we call the NAD+ cap. We show that this cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We also show that the NAD+ cap is produced cotranscriptionally, suggesting that it may regulate mRNA stability and/or translation. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which the 5′ cap structure regulates mRNA stability and translation. It also provides a starting point for understanding how the NAD+ cap may function in the cell. This work may also have implications for understanding the function of NAD+ in the cell.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control can prevent the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the long-term effects of intensive glucose control on the risk of macrovascular complications are unknown. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes persist for several years after the end of the DCCT and may be associated with the risk of macrovascular complications. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This work may help to explain the long-term benefits of intensive glucose control and may help to develop new therapeutic strategies for the prevention of macrovascular complications in people with diabetes. (Show more)

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and has no targeted therapy. We show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 is required for the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and for the growth of tumors in mice. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was confirmed by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that gut permeability is increased in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, and this alteration is associated with the increased gut permeability. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the volatile chemicals it produces during ripening. These compounds are produced by a complex network of biosynthetic enzymes, many of which are not known. We have identified a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a precursor to produce the final products. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the field of plant biochemistry. The gene identified here is a promising candidate for improvement of the flavor of tomato fruit. The pathway described here is also relevant to other species of the tomato clade, which are known to produce different mixtures of nitrogenous volatiles. This work also provides a model for the biosynthesis of other nitrogenous volatiles in plants. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for spatial memory, and its neurons exhibit spatial tuning. However, the spatial organization of these neurons is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are the main type of spatial neuron in MEC, are spatially segregated from other neurons, and that the spatial organization of grid cells is different from that of other neurons. These findings provide a detailed view of the spatial organization of MEC neurons and will be useful for understanding the function of MEC in spatial memory. This work also provides a method for recording the activity of a large number of neurons in freely moving animals. Such a method will be useful for studying the function of other brain areas.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental signals. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here we show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigrostriatum are integrated by specialized formations within the nigral system. These striosome–dendron bouquets, which are composed of striosomal fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites, are likely critical to the processing of dopamine-related information. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets may be a promising target for future studies of the mechanisms of Parkinson’s disease and other disorders of the dopamine system.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. This signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for regulating heart rate. SAN cells are specialized cardiomyocytes that are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that initiates each heartbeat. SAN cells are also responsible for maintaining heart rate in the face of changes in blood pressure and other hemodynamic demands. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN automaticity. We show that STIM1 is expressed in specialized cardiomyocytes in the SAN and that its deletion in mice leads to a reduction in the number of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ stores in SAN cells. These changes in SAN Ca2+ stores lead to a reduction in heart rate and to an exaggerated autonomic response to acetylcholine. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in regulating SAN Ca2+ stores and contribute to our understanding of how SAN automaticity is regulated. (Show more)

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by an increase in jasmonic acid (JA) signaling. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the mechanisms by which silicon may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect plants from insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by elevated neural activity. However, other work has suggested that short-term synaptic facilitation can also contribute to memory. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that is based on a mechanism that is sensitive to context and serial order. It is also consistent with recent findings in neuroscience that have shown that memory is dependent on the level of neuronal activity. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall and that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for successful delivery and gene silencing. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a foundation for the use of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and opens up avenues for the use of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to other organisms.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries is often overlooked in efforts to reduce coastal eutrophication. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large lakes, especially in the form of dissolved inorganic nutrients that are more bioavailable to algae. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries, which are often overlooked in regulatory efforts and in the public imagination. This approach could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

The study of chemical networks that are far from equilibrium is a central theme in modern biology and chemistry. In this work, we study a simple model of a chemical network that is far from equilibrium and is exposed to a strong environmental forcing. We find that the system exhibits a strong tendency to concentrate in states that extremize the environmental forcing. This extremization behavior is a consequence of the underlying network architecture and the environmental forcing, and it is not a feature of the underlying chemical kinetics. We discuss the implications of our findings for the study of far-from-equilibrium chemical systems.

The mechanisms by which antibodies can cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies that block the NMDA receptor can change the dynamics of the brain’s electrical activity, making it more susceptible to paroxysmal events. We use a mathematical model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. We then use a mouse model to show that these parameters are critical for the susceptibility of the brain to overt EEG paroxysms. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also provide a framework for understanding how other antibodies can cause seizures. This work may also lead to the development of new treatments for epilepsy. (Show more)

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 years. The cause of this warming is still under debate, but it is likely that the Earth system is responding to a perturbation in the carbon cycle. Here, we present evidence for a major carbon cycle perturbation and global warming event ∼304 Ma, which occurred during a glacial period. We show that the warming event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean and to anoxia of the ocean floor. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms of the current global warming and into the potential impacts of such a warming event on the carbon cycle.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. However, the impact of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that the benefits are limited by the fact that most plantations are small and contain little residual forest. Certification is also associated with reduced fire, but the impact on deforestation is likely to be small. Our results suggest that certification is not yet delivering on its promise to reduce deforestation, and that broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations are necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal life, and the genetic basis of sex is a key component of sex differences in morphology and behavior. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple alleles interact to produce a spectrum of sex classes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles interact to produce four possible sex classes. We find that multiple alleles can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the evolution of a new sex determiner can create additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of multiple alleles in the sex determination system.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of reactive intermediates of vitamin A that are generated by photooxidation and photodegradation of the lipofuscin-like pigments. These intermediates, which are known as “bisretinoids,” are toxic to photoreceptor cells. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in the retina, promote the photooxidation and photodegradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that the intracellular levels of iron may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of this disease. This is the first study to show that the levels of iron in the cell impact the photooxidation and photodegradation of bisretinoids. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in shaping the structure of food webs. In this study, we show that the evolution of siphonophore predators has been shaped by the diversification of prey types. We also show that the evolution of specialized predators is not a dead end, and that they can evolve into generalists. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide insights into the evolution of the most extreme specialization in the animal kingdom, which is the case of siphonophores.

The human hand is a complex and highly evolved structure, and the fossil record provides only a fragmentary view of its evolution. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from 1.42 million years ago that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding is consistent with the hypothesis that the evolution of the modern human hand was driven by the need to adapt to a more specialized diet and a more active lifestyle. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus cancer cells must meet the increased demand for one-carbon units for nucleotide synthesis. We have developed a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT) that is highly effective in cancer cells. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a cancer with a unique metabolic profile. These findings provide a metabolic rationale for targeting SHMT in DLBCL, and suggest that targeting the glycine import defect may be a general strategy for treating other cancers. This work provides a metabolic basis for the differential sensitivity of B-cell and non-B cell cancers to SHMT inhibition. These findings may also have implications for other cancers that depend on SHMT enzymatic activity for survival. (Show more)

The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with a growing global population and increasing demand for food, coupled with a lack of access to nutritious food. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by having access to natural landscapes such as forests. This study has important implications for policy makers, as forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but the increase in weight has also increased the risk of subsoil compaction. We show that the risk of subsoil compaction has increased over the course of modern mechanization, with the risk of compaction now exceeding safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We also show that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, suggesting that unconstrained roaming of these giants would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. Our results call for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. This may help to reduce the risk of subsoil compaction and improve the sustainability of modern agriculture.
